sub_topic: Finding the maximum and minimum values of a function
message_1: A water tank in the shape of a rectangular prism with length 6 meters, width 4 meters, and height 8 meters is being drained. The water level is currently 5 meters high. Let V(x) be the volume of water in the tank as a function of the height x (in meters) of the water level. What is the maximum volume of water in the tank? At what height is the water level to achieve this maximum volume?
message_2:
Since the water tank is in the shape of a rectangular prism, the volume of the water in the tank can be calculated using the formula:

V(x) = length × width × height

In this case, the length and width are fixed at 6 meters and 4 meters, respectively, while the height is variable (x). So, the volume function V(x) is:

V(x) = 6 × 4 × x
V(x) = 24x

The maximum volume of water in the tank occurs when the tank is completely full, which means the height x is equal to the maximum height of the tank, which is 8 meters.

So, the maximum volume of water in the tank is:

V(8) = 24 × 8
V(8) = 192 cubic meters

To achieve this maximum volume, the water level must be at the maximum height of 8 meters.
